contentrichtext.text: {{about|St. Adalbert of Magdeburg||Adalbert (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Adalbert of Magdeburg.jpg|200px|thumb]] '''Saint Adalbert of Magdeburg''' (also '''Saint Albert of Magdeburg''') (died 20 June 981), sometimes known as the '''Apostle of the Slavs''', was the first [[Archbishop of Magdeburg]] (from 968)<ref>{{cite book |title= Chambers Biographical Dictionary|last1=Thorne|first1=John|last2=Collocott|first2=T. C.|year=1990|publisher= Chambers|location= Edinburgh|isbn=0-550-16041-8|page= 7|oclc=502219677|origyear=1964}}</ref> and a successful missionary to the [[Polabian Slavs|Slavic peoples]] to the east of Germany. He was later [[canonised]]; his feast day is June 20. ==Life== Adalbert, possibly born in [[Alsace]], was a [[Germany|German]] [[monk]] at the [[Benedictine]] Monastery of Saint Maximinus in [[Trier]]. He was consecrated a [[bishop]] and in 961 he was sent to [[Kievan Rus]]. Princess [[Olga of Kiev]] had asked Emperor [[Otto I the Great|Otto the Great]] to provide her with a [[missionary]] from the [[Roman Catholic Church|Church of Rome]]. Her son, [[Svyatoslav I of Kiev|Svyatoslav]] opposed her and took her [[The Crown|crown]] from her as soon as Adalbert arrived in Kievan Rus. Adalbert's mission companions were slain and Adalbert was barely able to escape. Kievan Rus subsequently accepted conversion from [[Constantinople]] and [[Eastern Christianity|Byzantine Christianity]]. Upon escaping, Adalbert traveled to [[Mainz]], where he became abbot of [[Wissembourg]] in [[Alsace]]. Once there, he worked to improve the education of the monks. He later became [[archbishop of Magdeburg]], a city in [[Saxony-Anhalt]]. The archbishoprics of [[Archbishopric of Bremen|Hamburg]] and [[Archbishopric of Bremen|Bremen]] had been created with the intent that they would act as bases for missionary activity in northern and eastern Europe. The [[Archbishopric of Magdeburg]] was now designated to provide missionary programs for the eastern European [[Slavic peoples|Slavs]]. Adalbert also established dioceses at [[Diocese of Naumburg|Naumburg]], [[Diocese of Meissen|Meissen]], [[Diocese of Merseburg|Merseburg]], [[Bishopric of Brandenburg|Brandenburg]], [[Diocese of Havelberg|Havelberg]] and [[Diocese of Poznań|Poznań]] in [[Poland]]. A student in Adalbert's time who went on to do important work among the Slavs was Vojtěch of Prague, later canonized as Saint [[Adalbert of Prague]]. ==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book |title= The Penguin Dictionary of Saints|last1=Attwater|first1=Donald|authorlink= |last2=John|first2=Catherine Rachel|year=1995|publisher=Penguin|location=London|isbn=0-14-051312-4|oclc=60310282|edition=3rd|origyear=1965}} * {{Catholic|wstitle=St. Adalbert (of Germany)}} ==External links== *[http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=534 Catholic Online: Saints & Angels: St. Albert of Magdeburg] *[http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=1113 Catholic Online: Saints & Angels: St. Adalbert of Magdeburg] *[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1O100-AdalbertofMagdeburg.html HighBeam Research: Adalbert of Magdeburg] {{S-start}} {{s-hou|||c. 910 in [[Lotharingia|Lorraine]]|20 June|981 in Zscherben (part of today's [[Geusa]])|name=Adalbert, also Adalbert(us), Albert(us), Adelbert(us)}} {{s-rel|ca}} |- {{s-non | reason=new diocese}} {{s-ttl | title=[[Archbishopric of Magdeburg#Archbishops and administrators|Archbishop of Magdeburg]]|years=968–981}} {{s-aft | after=[[Gisilher]]}} {{S-end}} {{Authority control|VIAF=67262300}} {{Persondata | NAME = Adalbert of Magdeburg | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Archbishop of Magdeburg | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 981 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adalbert of Magdeburg}} [[Category:German Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:Archbishops of Magdeburg]] [[Category:10th-century archbishops]] [[Category:981 deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:German Benedictines]] [[Category:10th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:Benedictine bishops]]
